Nazi Policies Toward Jews and Minorities

abstract.p: Michael A Burstein letter says efforts to restore swastika to its original meaning as symbol of well-being and good fortune will never overcome its Nazi association (July 29 article)

block.p: Re ''A Symbol of Hatred Pleads Not Guilty'' (Arts & Ideas pages, July 29), about the goal of some people to redeem the swastika:
Re ''A Symbol of Hatred Pleads Not Guilty'' (Arts & Ideas pages, July 29), about the goal of some people to redeem the swastika:

The problem with trying to restore the swastika to its original meaning as a symbol of ''well-being and good fortune'' is that there are millions of people who will always react on a visceral level with fear and apprehension whenever one is displayed. Even if the person or group displaying it does not intend for it to carry a Nazi message, that association is inevitable.

Just like the Confederate flag, the swastika will forever carry frightening connotations. So long as there is one person to whom the swastika represents anti-Semitism and racial hatred, it cannot and should not be redeemed.
MICHAEL A. BURSTEIN Brookline, Mass., July 30, 2000
